description:
Influenza B virus is a type of the influenza virus that primarily infects humans. It is a member of the Orthomyxoviridae family, a group of enveloped, negative-sense, single-stranded RNA viruses. The Influenza B virus genome consists of eight gene segments that encode for various viral proteins, including the surface glycoproteins hemagglutinin (HA) and neuraminidase (NA).

Influenza B virus is known to cause seasonal epidemics, typically occurring during the winter months in temperate regions. Unlike Influenza A virus, which can infect a wide range of hosts, Influenza B virus is mainly restricted to humans, with occasional infections in seals and small whales. The virus is transmitted through respiratory droplets and direct contact with infected individuals or contaminated surfaces.

Influenza B virus can cause a range of respiratory illnesses, from mild, self-limiting cases to more severe manifestations, such as pneumonia and exacerbations of underlying medical conditions. Vaccination is the primary means of prevention, as it can provide protection against specific Influenza B virus strains that are predicted to circulate during a given influenza season.
